emergencies.name: heart attack
emergencies.description: Patient is experiencing symptoms of a heart attack, such as chest pain or pressure.
emergencies.steps: Have the patient sit down and rest. Give them an aspirin if they are not allergic. Monitor the patient's breathing and pulse, and be ready to perform CPR if necessary.

emergencies.name: stroke
emergencies.description: Patient shows signs of a stroke, such as facial drooping, arm weakness, or speech difficulties.
emergencies.steps: Lay the patient down with their head and shoulders slightly elevated. Do not give them anything to eat or drink. Monitor their condition and be prepared to perform CPR if they lose consciousness.

emergencies.name: choking
emergencies.description: Patient is choking and unable to breathe due to an obstruction in the airway.
emergencies.steps: Perform the Heimlich maneuver: Stand behind the patient, place your hands around their waist, and press inward and upward just above their navel until the object is expelled.

emergencies.name: burn
emergencies.description: Patient has sustained a burn injury, causing damage to the skin.
emergencies.steps: Cool the burn with running water for at least 10 minutes. Cover the burn with a sterile, non-stick bandage or clean cloth. Do not apply ice or butter to the burn.

emergencies.name: poisoning
emergencies.description: Patient has ingested or come into contact with a toxic substance.
emergencies.steps: Identify the poison and remove the patient from exposure. Call emergency services immediately. Do not induce vomiting unless instructed by a medical professional.

emergencies.name: anaphylaxis
emergencies.description: Patient is experiencing a severe allergic reaction, leading to difficulty breathing or swelling.
emergencies.steps: Administer an epinephrine auto-injector if available. Have the patient lie down and elevate their legs. Monitor their breathing and pulse, and be ready to perform CPR if necessary.

emergencies.name: broken bone
emergencies.description: Patient has sustained a fracture or broken bone.
emergencies.steps: Immobilize the injured area using a splint or sling. Apply ice to reduce swelling. Keep the patient calm and still until medical help arrives.

emergencies.name: not breathing
emergencies.description: Patient is not breathing or has stopped breathing.
emergencies.steps: Perform CPR: Push hard and fast in the center of the chest. Tilt the patient's head back and lift the chin. Blow air into their mouth until the chest rises.

emergencies.name: severe bleeding
emergencies.description: Patient is experiencing severe bleeding from a wound.
emergencies.steps: Apply pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage. Elevate the injured area above the level of the heart if possible.

emergencies.name: seizure
emergencies.description: Patient is experiencing a seizure, which may involve convulsions, shaking, or loss of consciousness.
emergencies.steps: Protect the patient from injury by moving objects away. Do not restrain them or put anything in their mouth. Once the seizure stops, place them on their side in the recovery position.

emergencies.name: drowning
emergencies.description: Patient has inhaled water and is struggling to breathe or is unconscious.
emergencies.steps: Remove the patient from the water and check for breathing. If they are not breathing, begin CPR immediately. Keep the patient warm after resuscitation.

emergencies.name: electric shock
emergencies.description: Patient has been exposed to an electrical current, resulting in potential injury or cardiac arrest.
emergencies.steps: Turn off the power source if possible before touching the patient. If the patient is unconscious and not breathing, begin CPR. Look for burn marks and treat them as necessary.

emergencies.name: hypothermia
emergencies.description: Patient's body temperature has dropped to dangerously low levels due to cold exposure.
emergencies.steps: Move the patient to a warm environment. Remove any wet clothing and wrap them in blankets. Provide warm (not hot) fluids if they are conscious. Monitor breathing and be ready to perform CPR.

emergencies.name: heatstroke
emergencies.description: Patient is suffering from heatstroke, characterized by a high body temperature, confusion, or loss of consciousness.
emergencies.steps: Move the patient to a cooler place. Remove excess clothing and cool them with damp cloths or a fan. Offer sips of water if they are conscious. Monitor for signs of worsening condition.

emergencies.name: allergic reaction (mild)
emergencies.description: Patient is experiencing a mild allergic reaction, such as itching, rash, or swelling.
emergencies.steps: Administer an antihistamine if available. Keep the patient calm and monitor for any signs of the reaction worsening. If the reaction becomes severe, treat as anaphylaxis.

emergencies.name: asthma attack
emergencies.description: Patient is having difficulty breathing due to an asthma attack.
emergencies.steps: Help the patient sit up and administer their prescribed inhaler. Encourage slow, deep breaths. If symptoms do not improve, seek emergency medical assistance.

emergencies.name: diabetic emergency
emergencies.description: Patient is experiencing a diabetic emergency, such as low or high blood sugar.
emergencies.steps: If the patient is conscious and able to swallow, give them a sugary drink or snack. Monitor their condition and seek medical help if they do not improve or if they become unconscious.

emergencies.name: panic attack
emergencies.description: Patient is experiencing a panic attack, characterized by intense fear, shortness of breath, and rapid heartbeat.
emergencies.steps: Encourage the patient to take slow, deep breaths. Reassure them that they are safe and the attack will pass. Help them find a quiet place to sit down and relax.

emergencies.name: eye injury
emergencies.description: Patient has sustained an injury to the eye, causing pain, vision loss, or bleeding.
emergencies.steps: Avoid touching or rubbing the eye. If there is a foreign object, do not attempt to remove it. Cover the eye with a clean cloth or shield and seek immediate medical attention.
